title.narrative: OUTPUT 5.3 WASH- COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT

description.narrative: By 2024, Parents, families, caregivers and communities have appropriate knowledge of and adopt good hygiene practices, and participate in the planning, construction and management of gender-sensitive Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) facilities in communities and institutions, including in humanitarian situations., which contributes to Reducing Child Poverty, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Partnerships And Engagement: Public And Private, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2024, significantly more communities in urban slums and rural areas, especially those who are marginalized and/or living in humanitarian conditions, reduce open defecation and adapt adequate hygiene practices, and institutions (schools and health care facilities) have access to safely managed water supply and sanitation and adopt adequate hygiene practices.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2024, Parents, families, caregivers and communities have appropriate knowledge of and adopt good hygiene practices, andparticipate in the planning, construction and management of gender-sensitive WASH facilities in communities and institutions,including in humanitarian situations.

description.narrative: About 155 communities were triggered as part of CLTS demand creation, and 104 communities achieved ODF status, benefiting 37,371 persons. ODF verification/ certification is ongoing for the rest of the 51 communities. Some 65,795 persons (38,852 male and 26,943 female) were provided with knowledge on health and hygiene through CLTS and hygiene promotion activities in five counties | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:25/01/2022
